page.title: 01Cereal Farming In England
page.content: This rural area with low population is wet and flat 0'-150' above sea level. Large fields are drained by man-made dykes and warping drains. Machinery is used to remove silt. One mile south a clough on river Ouse prevents land flooding. Crops - mainly cereals; Rape and vegetables. Minimal hedging and woodland. Narrow metalled roads allow passage of motorised vehicled. Footpaths connect small number of houses and farms. Light manufacturing industry centres round railway station in NE and this line, from Hull on the coast, links the inland port of Goole on the river Duse in SE-at the half-way point arte manned gates allowing vehicles across the lines. A secondary road across the NW connects the nearby towns of Howden and Gilberdyke. In SE-a line of pylons carries overhead
